questions.questionText: What does the <em> element tell the browser?
answers: That the text should be bold
That the text should be centered
That the text should be emphasized
That the text should be hidden
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! The <em> element tells the browser the text should be emphasized.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. The <em> element is used to emphasize text, like making it stand out.

questions.questionText: What happens when a style is applied to a parent element?
answers: Nothing happens to the child elements
Child elements can inherit that style
Only the first child gets the style
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! Child elements can inherit styles from their parent.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Child elements can inherit styles that are applied to their parent element.

questions.objectiveName: Understand the anatomy of an HTML page
questions.questionText: Which elements are nested inside the <html> element?
questions.correctResponse: Correct! The <head> and <body> elements are both nested inside the <html> element.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Both the <head> and <body> elements are inside the <html> element.

questions.objectiveName: Identify the most common HTML elements
questions.questionText: What does the <h1> element do?
answers: Wraps a block of quoted text
questions.correctResponse: Correct! The <h1> element creates the largest heading and is used for top-level titles.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. The <h1> element creates a large, top-level heading.

questions.objectiveName: Identify the most common HTML elements
questions.questionText: What's the purpose of the <span> tag?
answers: To break text onto a new line
To apply styling to part of a line
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! The <span> tag is great for styling specific words or phrases inline.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. The <span> tag is used to apply styling within a line of text.

questions.questionText: Where do you typically place attributes in an HTML element?
questions.correctResponse: Correct! Attributes are placed inside the opening tag of an HTML element.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Attributes belong inside the opening tag to modify behavior or appearance.

questions.questionText: In the style attribute, what separates multiple style rules?
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! Style properties are separated by semicolons within the style attribute.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. You separate style rules with semicolons.

questions.questionText: Which attribute would you use to link to another webpage?
questions.correctResponse: That's right! The href attribute is used to specify the URL in links.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. You use href to link to other pages.

questions.questionText: Why is it important to organize your HTML code?
questions.correctResponse: Correct! Organized code is easier to read, maintain, and work on with a team.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. The main reason is to improve readability and make maintenance easier.

questions.questionText: Which HTML tag is used for marking the head section of a page?
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! The <head> tag contains metadata, styles, and other crucial resources.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. The <head> tag is the right one for metadata and linking resources.

questions.questionText: What does the <ul> element represent in HTML?
questions.correctResponse: Correct! <ul> stands for unordered list, typically using bullet points.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. <ul> is used to create unordered lists.

questions.questionText: What is the main purpose of CSS?
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! CSS is used to style HTML elements—like colors, fonts, and layouts.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. CSS is used to style HTML content visually.

questions.questionText: What does it mean when a style 'cascades' in CSS?
answers: It flows from parents to children
questions.correctResponse: Correct! Cascading means styles can be inherited or overridden based on the structure.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Cascading refers to how styles are passed down and overridden.

questions.questionText: What is a downside of using inline styles too often?
answers: They make code harder to maintain
questions.correctResponse: Correct! Inline styles become messy and hard to update across a site.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Inline styles can be hard to maintain when overused.

questions.questionText: What tag is used to link an external stylesheet in HTML?
questions.correctResponse: That's right! The <link> tag connects your HTML to an external CSS file.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. You use the <link> tag to include a stylesheet.

questions.objectiveName: Understand the anatomy of a style
questions.questionText: In `color: red;`, what is 'color'?
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! 'color' is the property you're trying to change.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. In this case, 'color' is the property name.

questions.questionText: What does a class selector start with in CSS?
questions.correctResponse: Correct! Class selectors start with a dot (.) in CSS.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Class selectors use a dot, like `.highlight`.

questions.questionText: Which selector would target an element with the ID 'header'?
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! ID selectors start with a # symbol.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. To target an ID, use # followed by the ID name.

questions.objectiveName: Learn about the CSS box model
questions.questionText: What is the outermost part of the CSS box model?
questions.correctResponse: That's right! The margin is the outermost part that separates elements.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. The margin is on the outside of all other box parts.

questions.questionText: Which part of the box adds space inside the border but outside the content?
questions.correctResponse: Correct! Padding sits between the content and the border.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Padding is what adds space around the content inside the box.

questions.objectiveName: Set the width and height of a CSS box
questions.questionText: Which CSS property sets how wide an element is?
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! Use the width property to define how wide an element should be.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. The width property sets the element’s horizontal size.

questions.objectiveName: Learn HTML and CSS best practices
questions.questionText: Why are best practices important in web development?
answers: They make your code look colorful
They help your site load slower
They ensure your code is clean, readable, and consistent
They remove the need for testing
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! Best practices help keep code maintainable and understandable.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Best practices help make your code clear, clean, and collaborative.

questions.questionText: What do you put at the top of your HTML to tell the browser you're using HTML5?
questions.correctResponse: Correct! `<!DOCTYPE html>` is the declaration for HTML5.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. You declare HTML5 with `<!DOCTYPE html>` at the top.

questions.questionText: Why are external stylesheets preferred over inline styles?
answers: They load faster and are easier to manage
They make your site scroll faster
questions.correctResponse: Correct! Stylesheets keep code clean and can be reused across pages.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Stylesheets improve performance and organization.

questions.questionText: What can happen if you forget to close an HTML tag?
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! Unclosed tags can break layout and cause unpredictable issues.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Broken layout is a common issue when tags are left open.

questions.objectiveName: Save and check your work often
questions.questionText: What’s the benefit of checking your code frequently while working?
questions.correctResponse: Correct! Frequent checking helps you spot and fix errors before they grow.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. Checking often prevents bigger problems later.

questions.questionText: What is one benefit of using an IDE like VS Code?
answers: It helps with syntax highlighting and error detection
questions.correctResponse: Exactly! IDEs provide highlighting, suggestions, and error checking.
questions.incorrectResponse: Not quite. IDEs help highlight code and catch mistakes as you type.
